page.title: 05DIGSWELL HOUSE
page.content: Early in the eighteenth century an old manor house stood to the west of the present-day Digswell House. It was purchased in 1785 by George Nassau Clavering Cowper but was demolished in 1805. The new mansion was built by the Hon. Edward Spencer, who lived in Digswell House for several years after its completion in 1806. During the first World War Digswell House served as a hospital and nursing home for wounded Australian Officers. After the war, the house was placed on the market by Lord Desborough, the then owner; Sir Ebenezer Howard was the buyer. In the l950s a group of young artists took possession and in 1959 Countess Mountbatten of Burma officially opened Digswell House as an art centre which it remained until 1985 when Digswell House was sold.
